title: Boyz II Men’s Shawn Stockman defends Gina Rodriguez over the n-word
text:
Shawn believes Gina should ‘get a pass’ to using the n-word (Picture: Getty, @Gina Rodriguez/Instagram)

Boyz II Men singer Shawn Stockman has defended Gina Rodriguez against backlash she’s received for using the n-word, as he believes she is ‘black’.

The Jane The Virgin actress has been heavily criticised for singing along to Ready Or Not by The Fugees in an Instagram video, and saying the n-word which features in the lyrics.

Gina, 35, later posted a video apologising for using the offensive word and said she was a fan of Lauryn Hill.

But while Shawn, 47, admits that it’s easy to censor lyrics when singing along, he feels the backlash towards Gina is unwarranted because he sees her as ‘black’ due to her Puerto Rican heritage.

Speaking to TMZ, Shawn said: ‘Here’s my thing, she was singing a song and if you’re going to sing a song, make sure that you censor yourself. We can all censor ourselves as we’re singing right?’

Explaining his viewpoint, the R&B singer continued: ‘But as far as I’m concerned, she’s Latina right? Latina [is] black.

‘A lot of people don’t acknowledge that but she’s black. She’s from Puerto Rico. Puerto Ricans, Cubans, Dominicans, Mexicans believe it or not, we all here [rubs his skin], we all history.’

Gina has apologised for causing offence (Picture: Getty Images)

When asked by the photographer if Gina ‘gets a pass’, Shawn replied: ‘Yes, come on man, she’s cool.

‘She’s Latino. If you go to Puerto Rico right now there are people my shade right now.’

Shawn then compared Gina to Love & Hip Hop star Amara La Negra who has Dominican heritage but is of a darker skin tone.

The paparazzo challenged the comparison by stating: ‘But Gina don’t look like that though,’ to which Shawn replied: ‘Alright but she still got the gene. Puerto Ricans, Latinos, you’re all black.’

After Gina received further criticism for her first brief apology, she issued a full statement to Instagram on Wednesday, apologising for any ‘pain’ she may have caused.

‘In song or in real life, the words that I spoke, should not have been spoken. I grew up loving the Fugees and Lauryn Hill. I thoughtlessly sang along to the lyrics of a favorite song, and even worse, I posted it,’ the actress wrote.

‘The word I sang, carries with it a legacy of hurt and pain that I cannot even imagine.

‘What consequences I face for my actions, today none will be more hurtful than the personal remorse I feel. Watching my own video playing back at me, has shaken me to my core. It is humiliating that this has to be a public lesson but it is indeed a much deserved lesson.

‘I feel so deeply protective and responsible to the community of color but I have let this community down.’

She concluded the message: ‘I have some serious learning and growing to do and I am so deeply sorry for the pain I have caused.’

It’s not the first time Gina has found herself at the centre of a race row.

Last year, she was accused of being ‘anti-black’ when she claimed black women get paid more than their Latina and Asian counterparts in Hollywood.

description: Boyz II Men singer Shawn Stockman has defended Gina Rodriguez for using the n-word as he believes she is 'black'.
